# Organizing core research documents (2025-06-05 10:34:34)

_**User**_


You are a senior prompt engineer who turns messy questions into super-clear instructions for AI. Your job is to:

- Make questions crystal clear and specific

- Break big ideas into smaller, manageable pieces

- Make sure answers are practical and usable

- Think about who's asking and what they need

- Keep making the questions better and better

THE 3-STEP PROCESS

1. BREAKING THINGS DOWN

- Figure out what someone really wants to know

- Take big, confusing ideas and make them smaller

- Strip away anything that's not really needed

2. BUILDING THE PERFECT QUESTION

- Tell the AI exactly what job to do

- Give clear instructions about how answers should look

- Choose what kind of expert the AI should pretend to be

- Check if the question can be made even better

3. MAKING SURE IT WORKS

- Would this question get good answers every time?

- Could someone misunderstand this question?

- Does this fit what the person is trying to learn?

EXAMPLES OF GOOD QUESTIONS


Example 1: Bad Question ‚Üí Good Question

Bad: "How do I market my business?"

Good: "You're a marketing expert. Give me 3 marketing strategies that:

- Cost under $1,000

- Have worked for real businesses

- Can be started this week

Include exact steps and common mistakes."

Example 2: Bad Question ‚Üí Good Question

Bad: "How can I be more productive?"

Good: "You're a productivity coach. Give me a 7-day plan that:

- Improves how I use time

- Manages my energy

- Helps me focus better

Include real examples and ways to measure success."

Example 3: Bad Question ‚Üí Good Question

Bad: "Explain AI safety"

Good: "You're an AI expert. Explain AI safety like you're talking to a regular person. Break it down into:

- What could go wrong

- How we can prevent problems

- Real examples of AI safety issues

Include solutions and their pros/cons."

TEMPLATE FOR MAKING PERFECT QUESTIONS

Always structure questions like this:

"You are [type of expert]. Using simple terms, explain [topic]. Break it into [number] main parts. Give [specific examples or steps]. Make your answer [format type]. Think about [important factors]. Your answer should help [target audience] and show success by [how to measure it]."

IMPORTANT RULES

- Don't use complicated words unless needed

- Make sure questions can't be misunderstood

- Adjust questions based on who's asking

- Make sure answers will be actually useful

YOUR MAIN JOB

Turn any question into the clearest, most useful version possible. Make sure every question leads to answers that people can actually use in real life.

Remember: Your goal is to turn confusing questions into super-clear ones that get amazing answers from AI!

+ **üîπ Sales Techniques Used:**
+ - All three: upselling, cross-selling, suggestive selling
+ - Team has mixed strengths across techniques
+ - WhatsApp selling with photo styling suggestions
+ 
+ **üîπ Price Confidence:** 
+ - Score: 9/10 when ready to discuss
+ - Strategy: Sell features/benefits first, price comes last
+ - "Sell the dream first"
+ 
+ **üîπ Biggest Challenges:**
+ - Care instructions knowledge gap
+ - Price objections from customers  
+ - Comparison shopping challenges
+ - Stock movement taking staff away from customers
+ 
+ **üîπ Training Preferences:**
+ 1. Short mobile lessons (5-10 minutes)
+ 2. Voice coaching
+ 3. Role plays (friendly/unfriendly customers)
+ 4. Manager feedback & group discussions
+ 5. NOT long text documents
+ 
+ **üîπ Key Success Factors:**
+ - Physical presence needed for deeper training
+ - Self-paced flexibility crucial
+ - 5-6 hours per month maximum
+ - Data cost considerations for mobile training
+ - Immediate practical application essential

+ ## Key Insights
+ 
+ **üîπ Sales Techniques Used:**
+ - Cross-selling most common
+ - Focus on selling benefits before price
+ - Confidence varies by customer type
+ 
+ **üîπ Biggest Customer Objections:**
+ 1. "I'll come back later" (urgency)
+ 2. "I'll think about it" 
+ 3. Product availability (size/colour)
+ 
+ **üîπ Knowledge Gaps:**
+ - Care/maintenance instructions
+ - Product features (improving)
+ 
+ **üîπ Tasks Taking Staff Away from Customers:**
+ - Stock checks and inventory management
+ - Paperwork and admin tasks
+ 
+ **üîπ Training Preferences:**
+ 1. Short mobile lessons (10 minutes)
+ 2. In-person workshops
+ 3. WhatsApp voice notes
+ 4. Watching experienced staff (observation)
+ 5. NOT long written documents
+ 
+ **üîπ Training Barriers:**
+ - Work distractions during training
+ - Need to close business for effective training
+ - Prefer personal devices for mobile training
+ - Data costs a concern
+ 
+ **üîπ Success Metrics:**
+ - Daily sales targets most important
+ 
+ **üîπ Old Habits Hard to Change:**
+ - Not using suggested selling phrases
+ - Not approaching customers proactively  
+ - Not following up after sales

+ # FORJE RETAIL TRAINING PLATFORM - PROJECT CONTEXT
+ 
+ ## PROJECT OVERVIEW
+ **Status**: Research Phase (Dec 2024)
+ **Type**: Mobile-first B2B SaaS training platform for retail sales staff
+ **Problem**: Skill gaps in customer engagement, product knowledge, sales conversion
+ **Solution**: Bite-sized mobile training modules for retail environments
+ **Revenue**: Training licenses per retail location
+ 
+ ## CURRENT STRUCTURE
+ ```
+ 01-CORE/          # Landing page, deployment files
+ 02-RESEARCH/      # Interview insights, market research
+ 03-PARTNERSHIPS/  # FORJE + LBS Fashion Retail Programme proposal
+ 04-ASSETS/        # Brand materials, archived content
+ ```
+ 
+ ## KEY RESEARCH INSIGHTS (From Staff Interviews)
+ **Pain Points**:
+ - Price conversations & care instructions most challenging
+ - Work distractions interrupt training
+ - Data costs barrier for mobile learning
+ - Need physical presence for deeper training
+ 
+ **Preferences**:
+ - 5-10 minute mobile lessons preferred
+ - Visual/interactive over written content
+ - Immediate applicability to daily work
+ 
+ **Current Techniques**:
+ - Cross-selling most common approach
+ - Main objections: "I'll come back later", "I'll think about it"
+ - Daily sales targets primary success metric
+ 
+ ## PARTNERSHIP STATUS
+ - FORJE + LBS Fashion Retail Programme proposal submitted
+ - Targeting fashion retail sector initially
+ - B2B licensing model per location
+ 
+ ## TECHNICAL STACK

+ - Mobile-first responsive design
+

+ 1. Partnership response follow-up
